tasks.title: Remove the copy from the ascii art that says "parallel claude agents go BLAM!"
For the c (check) command, for tasks that have no commit on branche, also clearly it when they have no uncommited changes.

We created an apply function for tasks in review before. We haven't really updated it, so it might be outdated. In general, I wonder if it won't have the same kind of merge issues that we see with worktrees and it's why we created the smart merge. Do you think we should also create a smart apply? The idea of apply is that it stages cherry picks and stages the changes in the current main worktree, so that we can test them, and then lets the user either accept or undo them. Undo should clean up our current worktree again and revert it to how it was before the apply. And accepting should accept the changes into the commit. Do you think we could make something like that work? We could use the claude sdk session that's still running for the task, like we do with smart merge.

tasks.title: Have a look at the Kanblam mascotte and logo on the top right. Give it a cool ansi color scheme inspired by the word BLAM.

The project bar show the open projects and the last option is to open a new project. I notice that it says [2] right now. But we've assigned the numbers to the phase areas. The open project shortcut should use a char in the range [!@#$%^&*()_], so in this instance it should be [@] instead of two. Can you fix that and make sure that both the ui and key binding are adjusted?
The project bar and logo are now on separate lines. Could we have the mascotte overlay the project bar, so we need one fewer line at the top?
Allow me to not just ctrl-v images into the editor, but also accept dragging images onto the terminal in mac. Do you think you can make that work?

Add a couple ui hints:
- Show insert on the New Task bar (highlight i) as a hint that i will start a New Task
- When the application first opens, show: ↑↓←→ navigate   enter select   esc back   ctrl-c exit   ? help in the status bar. Let is decay after about 10 seconds.

I can't edit a divider's title when it's on the top of the list. Instead it edits the task below. All is fine when the divider is further down. And divider's persistence feels a bit shaky. I had a divider just dissapear on me. I overlapped one with another. And one of the two seems to be gone ever since. Dividers don't seem to be their own entity. They move with the task that they are underneath. THat's not supposed to happen. They should stay in their pane. Make them indendent entities with their own sort order. No backward compatibility needed. Let's clean up the data file and get rid of any mention of dividers as part of tasks.

When i start a task, the entire app freezes for a few seconds. I believe this is because we're running sync. Could you make it async, so that the app remains responsive as the new task is initialized? Make sure we loose none of the functionality and reliability and think about providing clear user feedback in case of problems/errors/tasks not starting as expected.
I'm curious what it would look like if the mascotte's legs that overlay the line of the kanban box would have one fewer dash between the "legs" and the end of the screen.

Let's change the project bar at the top. Let's make the make the first option always [!] +project, [@] first project, [#} second, etc

[!] opens the open project modal.

Let's work on the responsive design of the mascotte and wordmark. When the mascotte takes up more than 60% of the width of the screen or the screen's height is fewer than 30 lines, just show "KANBLAM" instead.

Right now, I think we could trigger merges for multiple worktrees at the same time, do a temporary apply of changes from another task. Apply multiple tasks at the same time.. Could those interfere with each other? Or should that not be an issue? If there is a real chance of interference, come up with a way to block doing multiple things that might conflict with each other at the same time and provide intuitive feedback in the ui about it.
Completely get rid of dividers as part of task lists. Remove the code and clean up the data file.

Let's improve the responsive design further. Keep the mascotte. This should make for a more narrow ansi illuestration that should keep thinngs balanced.

When showing the responsive (narrow) version of the wordmark on the top right, add one more dash after the part of the mascotte that is on top of the kanban box line. That should move the "legs" of the mascotte slightly to the left, aligning it where it should be. Keep as is on the full width wordmark and mascotte, no changes needed there.

Let's increase the handoffs between Claude Code CLI and the SDK. When we the user uses o to open the the session with Claude code and the terminal, the Claude instance might not be up-to-date if we ran more work in the sdk (right?)
We could just kill the claude session and restart it, but that assumes that that claude session isn't doing something useful. We need to detect whether Claude code is running. If it is, do not kill it. If it isn't AND we ran new sdk commands since the terminal was openen, kill (or reload/refresh claude if possible) the claude session and resume it with the right id, the way you always start it.
The other way around: if we have openend a terminal, claude might have continue a conversation in the CLI that was started as an SDK session. How can we make sure the SDK session picks up on those new steps in the session, if any? Can the SDK continue where the cli left of in a session that was then handed to and resumed in Claude code?
Also consider that we shouldn't' try to resume and sdk session when a claude session is actively working in that session. That's going to create divergence in the session.
